title: Tuning Personalized PageRank for Semantics-aware Recommendations based on Linked Open Data

author: Cataldo Musto, Department of Computer Science, University of Bari

segmentation: I'm Cataldo from University of Bari and in the next few minutes will introduce you our work about recommender systems and about the development of a framework for providing recommendation which exploits the information available in the linked open data cloud.
So.
In this presentation we'll talk about recommender systems.
This term typically describes a class of algorithms, with goal is to provide people with the suggestions.
These suggestions are personalized, so they are built on the ground of the preferences of the user, so their needs on contextual data, for example.

It's a very disruptive technology since almost every web company adopts a recommender system as a central part of their business to suggest movies on Netflix to provide recommendations about music in Netflix, or even to provide suggestions about starting to buy on Amazon as well.
Very large part of the revenues of Amazon are due to the effectiveness of its recommendation algorithm.
Basically we have literature 2 main classes of recommender system, collaborative filtering and content based filtering in collaborative.
Filtering the main idea is that the word recommendation process has to be driven on the ground of the preferences of the community.
So typically our collaborative recommendation algorithm suggests me items other users similar to me have liked in the past.
On the other side.
This social aspect is not exploiting the content based recommendation anymore.
Becausw content based recommender systems.

The suggestions are built on the ground of the textual features which describe the items I have liked in the past are built on the ground of the descriptive features we have available for the items such as the genre of a movie or the director of the movie as well.

Are similar to those, however, like in the past.
